intro: Holocheilus monocephalus, commonly known as the single-headed holoparasite, is a leafless, hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Orobanchaceae family. It lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on its host for nutrients, typically attaching to the roots of other plants. The plant is characterized by its single, elongated stem that terminates in a single flower, which is usually white or pale pink in color. It is native to arid regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in dry, sandy soils. Due to its specialized parasitic nature, it plays a unique role in its ecosystem, influencing host plant health and diversity.
